Shall_v. i. & auxiliary._ To owe; to be under obligation for._ To be obliged; must._" As an auxiliary
column2: shall indicates a duty or necessity whose obligation is derived from the person speaking; as
column3: you shall go; he shall go; that is
column4: I order or promise your going. It thus ordinarily expresses
column5: in the second and third persons
column6: a command
column8: or a promise. If the auxillary be emphasized
column9: the command is made more imperative
column10: the promise or that more positive and sure. It is also employed in the language of prophecy; as
column11: ""the day shall come when . . .
column12: "" since a promise or threat and an authoritative prophecy nearly coincide in significance. In shall with the first person
column13: the necessity of the action is sometimes implied as residing elsewhere than in the speaker; as
column14: I shall suffer; we shall see; and there is always a less distinct and positive assertion of his volition than is indicated by will. ""I shall go"" implies nearly a simple futurity; more exactly
column15: a foretelling or an expectation of my going
column16: in which
column18: a certain degree of plan or intention may be included; emphasize the shall
column19: and the event is described as certain to occur
column20: and the expression approximates in meaning to our emphatic ""I will go."" In a question
column21: the relation of speaker and source of obligation is of course transferred to the person addressed; as
column22: ""Shall you go?"" (answer
column23: ""I shall go""); ""Shall he go?"" i. e.
column24: ""Do you require or promise his going?"" (answer
column25: ""He shall go"".) The same relation is transferred to either second or third person in such phrases as ""You say
column26: or think
column27: you shall go;"" ""He says
column29: he shall go.""  After a conditional conjunction (as if
column30: whether) shall is used in all persons to express futurity simply; as
column33: or he shall say they are right.  Should is everywhere used in the same connection and the same senses as shall
column34: as its imperfect. It also expresses duty or moral obligation; as
column35: he should do it whether he will or not. In the early English
column36: and hence in our English Bible
column37: shall is the auxiliary mainly used
column40: v. t.) Shall may be used elliptically; thus
column41: with an adverb or other word expressive of motion go may be omitted."
